none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 25, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 25, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 11 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Brenham Texas
Jan 25 - 1882

My Dear Professor;
For two weeks I
have been suffering from cold -
in fact sick - hence my delay
in replying to your kind letter.
Dr. A. T. Spalding is pastor of First
Baptist Church Galveston - Dr G. W.
Rogers is pastor in Austin.
Dr Clopton, you know is bishop
in Brenham - "no mean city".
My impression is that Roberts
will again be Gov. of Texas.
Should the next Democratic Conven-
tion fail to nominate him, he
will be eliminated from Texas
politics, & think his chances for
U.S. Senatorship will be greatly
impaired; & he is astute enough
to know it. Coke is a hard
man to unhorse & he knows that.
In confidence I want to say to
you that his Excellency is the most
weird wizened apotheosis of

**My Transcription Process: A Detailed Analysis** Okay, here's the deal. I've got this image of a handwritten letter, and my goal is to produce an accurate transcription. First things first: I'm breaking down the image and analyzing its components. I need to nail down the origin (Brenham, Texas), the date (Jan 25, 1882), and the salutation ("My Dear Professor"). From there, I'm diving into the body of the text. I'm decoding the text line by line, paying attention to every word and symbol. There are some key individuals mentioned, like A. T. Spalding (pastor), G. W. Rogers (another pastor), and Dr. Clopton (the "bishop" of Brenham—that's interesting, might need to look into that title). Also, there are political figures, Governor Oran M. Roberts, and former Governor/Senator Richard Coke. So, I’m working up my transcription strategy. My strategy is to reproduce the text exactly, line by line, respecting line breaks, and using the right HTML tags: I'll put headers first. I need to format it appropriately, using `
` to maintain the line breaks as they are in the image. I have to avoid using ``, so I'm using `` for emphasis, which is how I’ll handle the underlined word "that." I'm also paying close attention to words that might be tricky, like "wizened" and "apotheosis," especially considering the letter's historical context. The phrase "weird wizened apotheosis of" is a bit ambiguous, but with some educated guesses, I think I'm getting the right sense of it. I want to respect the visual layout to the best of my ability, which includes line breaks and paragraph structure. There’s some back-and-forth about whether to use plus signs (+) or ampersands (&) for "and." I’m trying to be accurate to the original handwriting as much as possible, but where the symbol is ambiguous, I'm opting for the more likely intent. I'm also double-checking my HTML knowledge to be sure that I'm only using allowed tags. I need to be exact, so periods and punctuation marks are important. I'm checking spelling and names, like Clopton, Spalding, Rogers, Roberts, and Coke. Double-checking abbreviations like "Gov." and "U.S." Checking punctuation. I'm getting there. Finally, I’m ready to present the final, transcribed version. I've re-read it to catch any mistakes. The focus is always on accuracy and respecting the original document's structure and layout.

[1882, Jan. 25]

Demagoguism in Texas.
By the by, you see there is a "muss" in
the Executive family - Why don't the
"Siftings" man suggest a Commission
to harmonize the Gov. & his Cabinet?
Perhaps the "easiest way out" - without
regard to justice, honesty, manhood
or decency would be to declare
all the offices of the State government
vacant. It is quite another ox
that is being "gored". O that
Gathright were alive. Do you
know that but little of any of the
cloud that has oppressed me for
more than two years, has rifted
away - I may be oversensitive
but my heart often bleeds -
I try not to rejoice in the "death
of the wicked", but Dixon is
gone - Pickett is gone & others,
who sought or acquiesced in the
professional assassination of
innocent men - uncharged unheard
unarraigned will go. Perhaps I
ought not to think or write about this matter

**Image Analysis and Transcription: A Deep Dive**

Okay, here's what I've got. This looks like a fascinating piece of 1882 Texas history, likely a letter or journal entry. The date's clear: [1882, Jan. 25], and it's all in that familiar, slightly loose cursive of the era. The ink is a lovely purple-blue.

First, I had to make sure the "Executive family" word was "Executive," even though the handwriting was a bit messy. Initially, I thought it might have been "Redemption family," which would have fit the political context of the "Redeemers" in post-Reconstruction Texas, but "Executive" fits with the "Cabinet" and "Gov." Later in the document.

The handwriting had me second-guessing myself with that first letter on line 12 as well. I considered, "Latimer", "Cartwright", "Garfield" and even "Gatling" and "Sutwright" before realizing it had to be a "Gathright." This Thomas S. Gathright was the first president of Texas A&M and died in 1880, which perfectly aligns with the writer's complaint about oppression "for more than two years" and the lament, "O that Gathright were alive." This confirmed the political context.

There's a definite political slant here, a strong sense of grievance. The writer is clearly concerned about "demagoguism in Texas" and mentions a "muss" in the Executive branch. The author also makes references to the "Siftings" newspaper, and the desire to see a "Commission" started to fix the situation in the state of Texas.

The language is loaded. Phrases like "professional assassination" and "death of the wicked" point to a deep-seated anger and possibly a sense of betrayal. The writer seems to be lamenting the passing of Gathright. The "Dixon" and "Pickett" figures mentioned were probably political figures the writer disliked, and references to "uncharged unheard unarraigned" men add a layer of legal commentary. It gives the impression of a writer involved in the system who is now deeply disillusioned. I went over the transcription many times and have provided it as accurately as possible. The line breaks have also been preserved.

[1888, Jan 25]

You see from the papers that a
"Crum from the masters table"
has fallen to Prof. H. When I read
the paragraph I could but exclaim;
"O Judgment thou art fled to brutish beasts"
I never wished to see you so much
as now - While the world is cold &
selfish I feel that there are some
warm hearts in it.
Rumor has it that our friend
Moore will make a new departure
soon - His health has been feeble
for some months - A long letter
from you & some genial sunshine
would do me much good.
Your friend
Hana

**Image Analysis and Transcription Thoughts**

Okay, here we go. I'm looking at this handwritten document. It appears to be a letter. First, I need to get a handle on the overall structure and any distinguishing features. The top right corner has a penciled date: [1888, Jan 25]. That's likely an archival addition, but it's important context. The body is in purple ink, which is interesting. I will go through the image and think aloud as I perform a transcription.

The handwriting is cursive. Let's see... Line 1: "You see from the papers that a". Ok, no major issues there. Line 2: "Crumb from the masters table". That's a quote, so I need to preserve the quotation marks. The word "masters" is written as such, no apostrophe before the s. On to line 3. Line 3: "has fallen to Prof. H. When I read". Prof. H. is probably a person. We'll have to see if we can identify them later. Line 4: "the paragraph I could but exclaim;". Another easy one. Now the next line, Line 5: "O Judgment thou art fled to brutish beasts". Another quote, it seems. I should enclose that in quotation marks. Line 6: "I never wished to see you so much". Ok, no issue. Line 7: "as now - While the world is cold &". Okay, a dash and then the ampersand. Good. Line 8: "selfish I feel that there are some". Nothing extraordinary so far. Line 9: "warm hearts in it.". Okay.

Let's keep going. Line 10: "Rumor has it that our friend". Line 11: "Moore will make a new departure". Moore is probably another person, or a proper noun. I should note the word new because it is legible, Line 12: "soon - His health has been feeble" Okay, so "Moore" is probably related to this letter's contents. Okay, health: legible. Line 13: "for some months - A long letter". Okay. Now the interesting line, Line 14: "from you & some genial sunshine". Genial... that's the word. Hmm, the handwriting gets a little scrawly there. It looks like it is `g-e-n-i-a-l` then something after that? The next word after some is likely two words that are cramped together, let's see, it is most probably: genial sunshine. The letters are a bit blurred. But contextually, I am sure that is what it is. I'll need to double check that, but that's my interpretation for now. A long letter from you and some genial sunshine would fit this context, with a cold world and warm hearts. Line 15: "would do me much good.". Then there is a closing. Line 16: "Your friend". And the signature, Line 17: "Hana". Or "Hand". Looks like Hana. Let me make a good determination based on how this handwritten letter forms the letters and characters.

Let's look more closely at the signature. I'm going to look at the 'H' in the signature compared to the 'H' in "His" (line 12). Looks similar. The end character loops over the top. Could be an "a" or a "d", but given how most signatures are first names, it's likely Hana. Let me confirm some other letter formations like the 'd' in "good" and "world."

"Hand" is a weird name. "Hana" seems better, it's also a more common name. I will proceed with "Hana".

Now, let's look at that word "genial sunshine". It's a bit hard to read. Hmm, the start looks like `g e n i a l` then `s u n s h i n e`. The second word is `s u n s h i n e`. The `n` in genial is a little messy, but I'm confident that it is the intended word based on the overall tone of the letter. I will make a good judgement, given that Shakespeare is referenced in the text. I think "genial sunshine" fits the context very well. The `s` at the start of "sunshine" has a little loop on top. Looks like the `s` in "see". I am re-examining it now, `g e n i a l s u n s h i n e`. I'm confident.

Now, I'll transcribe this draft.
